Course Objectives

By the end of this course, you will be able to

  • Identify the characteristics of student-centered learning

  • Discuss the benefits of student-centered learning and the implications for the teacher’s role

  • Demonstrate understanding of how to apply research on learner motivation and persistence in adult literacy programs and the impact of student-centered learning on motivation and persistence

  • Describe strategies for implementing student-centered learning

  • Identify changes teachers can make to ensure that their classrooms are learner-centered

Course Expectations

You are expected to read and post at least once in each forum (not each discussion thread) and journal; watch recorded presentations; read the background readings and resource pages of the course; and complete at least one of the assignments and the final evaluation. You can expect to complete this course in approximately 6 hours as you explore strategies for creating a student-centered learning environment and for applying those strategies to the adult education context. 

If you are taking the writing track in this course, refer to the Key Shifts section of the College and Career Readiness Standards for Adult Education.

If you are taking the math track in this course, use the Standards for Mathematical Practice found in the College and Career Readiness Standards for Adult Education.  These standards represent processes and proficiencies that students at any NRS level should use and develop as they learn.
